article.h1: Study of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe intermetallic compounds: an LDA classification and hybridization effects

div.p: Spin-polarized calculations within the LDA approximation have been done with the goal of characterizing Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe intermetallic compounds. Symmetry and chemical environment effects on 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f hybridization and, thereafter, on magnetization effects have been studied.

In the last decades, Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe intermetallic compounds have received a lot of attention both in theory and experiment. On one side, these systems can exhibit a large variety of behaviors, such as superconductivity, huge magnetoresistance, itinerant magnetism, etc. On the other side, the nature of the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f states is controversial since it has not been established yet which systems can be treated using a bandlike picture and which ones using a localized one. In the first picture, the effective electronic correlation is weak and the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f states form a narrow band[1], while in the second one, the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electrons are highly correlated and interact weakly with the conduction band[2].

The main difference between Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe and other rare earth systems is that, in the case of Ce, the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f state is energetically very close to the Fermi level so that its occupation number and the strength of hybridization with the conduction electron bands strongly depend on the chemical and geometrical environment. In that sense , we can understand the complexity of the phase diagram of pure metallic Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe which, depending on temperature and pressure, can be magnetic, paramagnetic or superconducting[3]. Due to this fact, different types of magnetism have been observed within the intermetallic compounds: intermediate valence behavior, Kondo effect and magnetic ordered structures (FM, AF) are among them[4]. Intermediate valence behavior appears in systems having the states with nğ‘›italic-nn and n-1ğ‘›1italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n-1 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electrons almost degenerate. The nearly degenerate condition is a consequence of hybridization of the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f states and results in a configuration with a non integer electronic occupation number n4â¢fsubscriptğ‘›4ğ‘“italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{4f}. In general, intermediate valence materials show anomalous values for some physical properties such as lattice parameter, bulk modulus, magnetic susceptibility, etc, as compared to systems with an integer 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f occupation number. The intermediate valence behavior in Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds is characterized by having a very small or zero magnetic moment[5].

The different physical situations posed by these systems have been traditionally described by many body hamiltonians which consider strong electron-electron interactions and treat hybridization as a small perturbation. Kondo systems, for which correlations are dominant, have to be treated with these model hamiltonians. In Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe intermetallics, particularly, it is not clear at all how important the relative strength of hybridization and correlations are. There are systems whose electronic ground state can be well described by an itinerant picture, namely those in which 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f hybridization plays a relevant role giving rise to a decrease in correlation effects[6].

In this work our aim is twofold. First we want to use the band picture to establish a criterion for characterizing the ground state of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe intermetallic compounds by analysing their LDA spin contribution to the magnetic moment. As a second goal, and using for this the established criterion as a tool, we also want to analyse the dependence of the magnetism of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe on geometrical and chemical environment. For this we study a variety of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds, whose magnetic properties are experimentally well known. We claim that it is possible to determine to which regime the system under study belongs. That is, if we are dealing with strongly hybridized or strongly localized systems, going through the intermediate situations, by analysing the itinerant magnetic contribution that results from spin polarized LDA calculations. This analysis is certainly done in the knowledge that only those Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds whose 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f states are essentially itinerant can be well described within the LDA band theory frame. Actually, a proper treatment for the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electrons would be to include the self-interaction correction (SIC)[7] in the calculations but this is not necessary for the kind of description undertaken in this work.

Once we have established our characterization tool, we discuss the relative importance of chemical and crystalline environment on hybridization and thereafter on the determination of the magnetic state of intermetallic systems of the type Câ¢eâ¢Xnğ¶ğ‘’subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›italic-C italic-e italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeX_{n} with nğ‘›italic-nn equal or larger than one.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II we report the results of calculations done for several real systems and present a discussion of how the LDA approximation can be used to classify them into magnetic, intermediate valence or paramagnetic compounds. In the second part of this section we analyse the influence of chemical and structural environment on the magnetic ground state of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds. We finally present the conclusions in Sec. III.

In this work we perform ab-initio calculations using the Full Potential Linearized Augmented Plane Waves (FP-LAPW) method in the Local Density Approximation (LDA)[8]. We use the exchange and correlation potential of J.P. Perdew and Y. Wang[9]. We make both paramagnetic and spin polarized calculations. The sampling of the Brillouin zone used to calculate the electronic ground state depends on the size and symmetry of each system. In general, from 800 to 1400 k-points in the first Brillouin zone are enough for convergence. section.h3: II.1 Characterization of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds through their LDA magnetic moments

div.p: It is well known that Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe has one 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electron in the solid. As we have mentioned before, the energy of this 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f state is very close to the Fermi level so that it is, in principle, very sensitive to chemical and geometrical environment. In some compounds Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe keeps its magnetic moment equal to 1 Î¼Bsubscriptğœ‡ğµitalic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} and in others it can decrease even going to zero. In this Section we establish a way of characterizing Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds which allows us to classify them into magnetic, intermediate valence or paramagnetic by doing LDA spin polarized calculations. To achieve this we study compounds whose magnetic properties have already been reported and are listed in Table I.

Table I contains the structural data and the experimental ordering temperatures, TCsubscriptğ‘‡ğ¶italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{C} and TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N}, which correspond to the Curie and NeÃ¨l temperatures depending on whether the compounds are ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic. No magnetic order has been experimentally observed for the cases where no ordering temperature is shown[12].

In our calculations three types of magnetic configurations are possible: paramagnetic (P), ferromagnetic (F) and antiferromagnetic(AF). In Table I we also list the more stable configuration and the obtained LDA magnetic moment of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe for the different compounds. The calculations are performed at the experimental volumes shown in the same table.

The obtained magnetic moments for the compounds Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi, Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢hğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…â„italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-hCeRh and Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢d3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‘3italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCePd_{3} are far from being 1Î¼Bsubscriptğœ‡ğµitalic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} but they are clearly not zero so that we cannot consider them as being paramagnetic. An intermediate valence system is usually defined in the literature as one having in the average a non integer number of 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electrons.

div.p: The systems that are accepted to be itinerant, such as Câ¢eâ¢Nğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘italic-C italic-e italic-NCeN and Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢h3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…subscriptâ„3italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeRh_{3}, are the ones whose magnetic moment is exactly equal to zero. That is, when in a given Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe system the magnetic moment is zero the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electrons have a strong itinerant character.

In Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds the degree of localization is closely related to the strength of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe hybridization and consequently to the magnetic state. Let us take two extreme situations as examples, Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢h3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…subscriptâ„3italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeRh_{3} and Câ¢eâ¢Aâ¢gğ¶ğ‘’ğ´ğ‘”italic-C italic-e italic-A italic-gCeAg. In Figure 1 we show an electronic charge density plot corresponding to one of the Kohn-Sham orbitals with energy close to the Fermi level and with 90%percent90NUMBER:90 POSTFIX:percent90\% of 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f character. In the Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢h3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…subscriptâ„3italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeRh_{3} case, there is a mixing between Râ¢hğ‘…â„italic-R italic-hRh and Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe states near EFsubscriptğ¸ğ¹italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{F} while, this is not the case for Câ¢eâ¢Aâ¢gğ¶ğ‘’ğ´ğ‘”italic-C italic-e italic-A italic-gCeAg, as can be clearly seen in Figure 1.

We can also analyse the degree of hybridization by comparing 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f and 4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d partial densities of states (Figure 2). The most striking difference between Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢h3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…subscriptâ„3italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeRh_{3} and Câ¢eâ¢Aâ¢gğ¶ğ‘’ğ´ğ‘”italic-C italic-e italic-A italic-gCeAg systems is that in the last one, the 4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d and 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f bands are approximately 4 eV apart being both of them very narrow, of the order of 1eV, while in Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢h3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…subscriptâ„3italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeRh_{3}, the 4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d band is more extended in energy (about 4eV), leading to an energy region around the Fermi level where hybridization is important. Thus, taking into account the calculated magnetic moments and using the established criterion, we say that in the compound where the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f band is more hybridized, namely Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢h3ğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…subscriptâ„3italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCeRh_{3}, the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f band turns more delocalized leading thus to a non magnetic Ce. This should hold in general.

section.h3: II.2 Dependence of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe magnetism on crystalline and chemical environment

div.p: Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe can completely or partially loose its magnetic moment depending on chemical and crystalline environment. In this section we study how 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f hybridization affects the Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe magnetic moment depending on the local symmetry and the chemistry of the ligand. The 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f band hybridizes not only with 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f electrons of neighboring Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe sites but also with orbitals of the ligand (4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d, 3â¢d3ğ‘‘NUMBER:3 italic-d3d or sâ¢pğ‘ ğ‘italic-s italic-psp bands). Both types of hybridization produce a decrease in the magnetic moment of Ce.

For the symmetry considerations, we compare systems of the type Câ¢eâ¢Xğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘‹italic-C italic-e italic-XCeX (X=Ni, Rh, Pd) and analyse them in the CrB and CsCl crystal structures. These structures are being taken as prototypes of different symmetries within the same relative composition. Actually, both structures appear in nature associated with Câ¢eâ¢Xğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘‹italic-C italic-e italic-XCeX compounds. In general, when X is a latter TM the observed structure is CrB and when X belongs to the 1B, 2B or the 3A column of the periodic table the corresponding structure is the CsCl one.

The calculation for a given Câ¢eâ¢Xğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘‹italic-C italic-e italic-XCeX system in both the CrB and the CsCl structures helps us to understand how local symmetry affects 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f hybridization and consequently the magnetization of Ce. The calculations within the CrB structure are performed at the experimental equilibrium volume at room temperature and, since the CsCl structures are hypothetical ones for Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi, Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢hğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…â„italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-hCeRh and Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-dCePd, we take the same volume per atom as in CrB in order to be able to compare the outcoming magnetic properties.

From Table II we see that the CsCl structure favours magnetism, even if slightly, as compared to the CrB one. This is a consequence of CsCl having higher symmetry. Crystal field effects lead, in the CrB case, to a lifting of almost all of the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f degeneracies while this is not the case in the CsCl structure. Within a â€™quasiâ€™-Stoner image CsCl favours magnetism due to a higher density of states at the Fermi level. This is coherent with the fact that only some of the CrB compounds are magnetic while all of the CsCl ones are magnetic.

The amount of total interstitial charge is practically the same in both structures: CrB and CsCl structures have 4.4 and 4.3 interstitial electrons per formula unit respectively. The difference among them comes from the spatial distribution of charge.

For the systems under study which crystallize in the CsCl structure, symmetry makes a contribution to the magnetic moment of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe, but it is actually not the crystalline environment the determining factor for the magnetic behavior. It is rather the chemical nature of the ligands the one that is responsible for this magnetic result. Considering for instance, the Câ¢eâ¢Aâ¢gğ¶ğ‘’ğ´ğ‘”italic-C italic-e italic-A italic-gCeAg or Câ¢eâ¢Câ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ¶ğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-C italic-dCeCd system from the previous section, which crystallize in the CsCl structure, the 4d band lies very low in energy and thereafter there is nearly no hybridization betwen 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f-4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d bands, leading this to the magnetization of Ce. In the hypothetical situation that one could force these systems to crystallize in the CrB structure they would also be magnetic.

On the other hand, if we compare the magnetization of Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi, Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢hğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…â„italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-hCeRh and Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-dCePd focusing on the CrB structure, which is the real one for these compounds, we can get insight into the effect that the type of ligand has on the magnetic moment of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe. Using our criterion Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-dCePd is a magnetically ordered system, while Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢hğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…â„italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-hCeRh and Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi are not when considered in their natural CrB structure. In Figure 4 we show the densities of states for the three compounds. The different magnetic solutions within the same crystalline structure can be explained, by the fact that in Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢hğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…â„italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-hCeRh the 4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d band is closer in energy to the Fermi level than in the Pâ¢dğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-P italic-dPd compound and consequently 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f-4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d hybridization is stronger. The more the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f band hybridizes with the 4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d band the smaller is the Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe magnetic moment. On the other hand, in the Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi case, there is an interplay between two types of hybridization namely Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe-Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe and Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe-Nâ¢iğ‘ğ‘–italic-N italic-iNi, both induce a decrease of the magnetism of Ce as compared to Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-dCePd. Actually, in Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi, there is a reduction in volume and Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe atoms are nearer to each other than in CePd. Consequently, as can be seen from the densities of states in Figure 4, the 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f band is 0.5 eV wider in Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi than in Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-dCePd due to an increase in Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe-Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe mixing. On the other side, the 3â¢d3ğ‘‘NUMBER:3 italic-d3d band lies nearer to EFsubscriptğ¸ğ¹italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{F} than the 4â¢d4ğ‘‘NUMBER:4 italic-d4d one this giving rise to 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f-3â¢d3ğ‘‘NUMBER:3 italic-d3d mixing. Due to this interplay Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi is the less magnetic compound among the CrB systems.

In this contribution using an itinerant picture we show that it is possible to characterize the magnetic ground state of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe intermetallic compounds by doing ab-initio calculations within the LDA approximation. This criterion allows us to classify them into magnetically ordered, intermediate valence or paramagnetic systems trough their calculated spin contributions to the Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe magnetic moment. It is based on the band theory frame in which, in general, correlated Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe systems are not well described. However we find that it is an usefull tool to obtaine qualitative information about the electronic ground state of a wide variety of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe compounds, including those with strong electronic correlations.

We study the importance of 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f hybridization in determining the magnetic state of Câ¢eğ¶ğ‘’italic-C italic-eCe by analysing both symmetry and chemical effects. We study first the influence of the symmetry environment on 4â¢f4ğ‘“NUMBER:4 italic-f4f hybridization in Câ¢eâ¢Nâ¢iğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–italic-C italic-e italic-N italic-iCeNi, Câ¢eâ¢Râ¢hğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘…â„italic-C italic-e italic-R italic-hCeRh and Câ¢eâ¢Pâ¢dğ¶ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ‘‘italic-C italic-e italic-P italic-dCePd and take CsCl and CrB as prototypes of high and low symmetry structures. We see that CsCl slightly favour magnetism as compared to CrB.
